nodes.text: Subjective, classroom-observation based teacher evaluation can produce lasting improvements in teacher effectiveness (skill or effort) that increase student math achievement after the evaluation year

Context: Cincinnati Public Schools implemented a Teacher Evaluation System (TES) with year-long observation-based evaluations, peer and administrator observers, rubric scoring, written feedback, and summative domain scores; most teachers were evaluated every five years

Method: Teacher fixed effects estimation comparing within-teacher student math test score outcomes before, during, and after a teacher's TES evaluation year, controlling for student observables, grade-by-year fixed effects, and a quadratic in teacher experience

Data: Analysis sample of 105 mid-career fourth through eighth grade math teachers hired 1993-1999 and 14,331 student-year observations from 2003-2004 to 2009-2010, matched to TES participation years, observation dates, and scores

Assumption: Timing of a teacher's TES evaluation year (phase-in schedule and actual year) is plausibly exogenous to unobserved within-teacher student assignment trends after controlling for observables, experience, and grade-year effects

TES features: multiple classroom observations per evaluation year, rubric based on Danielson framework, peer evaluator training, written feedback after observations, and final summative domain scores used sparingly for formal consequences
Result: Preferred estimates show no significant preexisting upward trend in years before evaluation and allow grouping all preevaluation years as the omitted baseline in treatment parameterization

Result: Main specification estimates students taught after a teacher's TES evaluation score on average 0.112 standard deviations higher in math than those taught by the same teacher before evaluation; estimate for year of evaluation is positive but smaller and not always significant

Robustness: Event study plots, alternative specifications separating immediate and later post years, using scheduled evaluation year, and 2SLS instrumenting actual timing with scheduled timing produce similar postevaluation gains, reducing concerns about strategic timing bias

Heterogeneity result: Postevaluation gains are largest for teachers with low preevaluation test-score value-added, for teachers with low TES scores, and for teachers whose TES scores increased most during the evaluation year; gains larger for math specialists than for self-contained teachers

Attrition and selection checks: Attrition rates after evaluation are low and similar to district patterns; restricting to teachers observed both before and after or weighting by inverse persistence probabilities yields similar or larger postevaluation estimates, indicating attrition unlikely to explain results

Interpretation claim: The pattern of results is consistent with an information mechanism in which evaluation provides individualized feedback prompting skill acquisition, sustained effort changes, or both, rather than solely proximate incentive effects

Limitation: Data do not identify the exact behavioral or pedagogical changes that caused the gains so mechanisms cannot be definitively proven; reading achievement shows no significant postevaluation gains in this sample

Cost and tradeoff claim: TES incurred direct budget costs about 1.8 to 2.1 million dollars per year or about 7,500 dollars per teacher evaluated, plus opportunity cost of withdrawing effective teachers to serve as peer evaluators; net productivity tradeoff depends on evaluator selection and number of teachers who benefit

Conclusion: Well-structured subjective teacher evaluation can function as an effective form of professional development that raises long-run teacher effectiveness and student math achievement; implications extend to reconsidering returns to subjective evaluation in other sectors
